The biennial will also feature an exhibition of sculptural works by artists such as Jan and Jan von Praem, who are collaborating again this year.The exhibition will be hosted by the Kunsthalle Basel in collaboration with the BMW Group and will be curated by Markus Schäfer, the director of the Kunsthalle Basel. The last few years have seen a series of exhibitions of work by women artists, many of whom are taking part in the first exhibition scheduled for the autumn. Among the first artists to receive commissions from the Kunsthalle Basel are Marina Schäfer, Anna Bächli, Irene Reed, and Hanna Škoda, who are all collaborating again this year. The Kunsthalle is also organizing a special exhibition dedicated to the Swedish artist Katjaa Aarhus.

The Seattle Asian Art Museum (SAAMI) has received a gift of eighty-one works by seventy-four contemporary artworks from the collection of Roberta Kass. The Austin Art Museum has added seven new artists to its collection: Poppy Harlow, Katherina Maldonado, and Christine Hooper. Harlow graduated from Texas Southern College in Austin and worked as a curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York. She currently works as a freelance curator, where she curated the 2013 exhibition “Thinking About Politics: Poppy Harlow” at the Whitney Museum of American Art. “I’ve known Poppy Harlow since her early paintings,” said museum director and CEO Jan Goldsmith. “Her bold, politically charged, and often surrealist paintings, which reflect an intuitive understanding of the visual world, and her vivid, sometimes disturbing, sculpture, which elegantly blends the physical and the spiritual, are considered classics.”Commenting on the museum’s selection, Harlow said: “In addition to being a master of art, I’ve been inspired by the museum’s collection and the people who have worked here over the last fifteen years.
